fields.description:
/var/run is backed by RAM on certain system (notably ubuntu by default and my lapotp) hence saving iptables-preload there is a bad idea, since it will be delete every reboot.

Perhaps should we have it in /etc/eucalyptus/net?
fields.summary: Eucalyptus should not use /var/run to save iptables-preload

comments.body: I observed a similar situation on a Centos 6.3 system: upon reboot the file is gone. /var/run was not mounted as tmpfs, and tmpwatch doesn't seem to be configured to touch //var/run/eucalyptus, yet that directory is clean upon reboot.

It is also not quite clear how to have these rules applied reliably in an HA environment. I had the system running, I stop one CC and added the file with 1 rule and started the CC: rules was not there. I tried with a combination of cleanstop, cleanstart, and cleanrestart to no avail. 

Adding the rule by hand gets removed upon failover or restarting of the CC. These tests were done in a 3.0.2 environment.

adding a command like

cp /etc/eucalyptus/iptables.save /var/run/eucalyptus/net/iptables-preload 

to rc.local seems to allow for the rule to appears upon reboot, but after the CLC starts and HA kicks in, the rule disappeared (the CC was DISABLED, and once the CLC came up, the CC cleared the state).
action for Graziano to split 2nd ticket for HA operation.
created different ticket for the HA failover issue.
Moved to confirmed to be reviewed by Engineering in bug scrub.
should go to /etc
Where and when is these file(s) created ?

Hey John.

This file is created in the CC if additional iptable rules are required for the system to function properly,
http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/3.1/ig/configuring_iptables.html

A real use case would be EUCA-2278, in this case an additional iptable rule is required.

{noformat}

1. It appears the entire Eucalyptus product uses ${EUCALYPTUS}/var/run/eucalyptus/ to store temporary
files.

 2. The CC relies on a fixed pathname in the configuration space (/var/run/eucalyptus) 
    to locate configuration files. 

3. Moving the iptable-preload file to a different filesystem will require changes 
   to the packaging ( we need to create /etc/eucalyptus/net ), documentation, 
   and a means to inform  vnetwork.c -> vnetLoadIPTables() where to find it. 



{noformat}
thanks for the feedback. You hit the problem squarely: iptables-preload is not temporary nor eucalyptus generated as most (hopefully all) the other files residing in /var/run/eucalyptus.
Make it look for {{/etc/eucalyptus/cc-iptables-preload}} instead and you don't have to wait for packaging changes at all.

One-time migrations are the job of packaging code anyway (see EUCA-4702); why not just let that take charge of migration and then noisily fall back to the old file name if the old one exists and the new one does not?

File /etc/eucalyptus/iptables-preload does not get picked up when CC enters ENABLED state. Performed service eucalyptus-cc cleanrestart and stop-start with new iptables rules added in /etc/eucalyptus/iptables-preload. These rules were not applied after CC flushed iptables rules when it changed its state to ENABLED.
Submitted to master/3.2/testing
This is one of those important behavioral changes that need to be explicitly called out in the release notes and the field should probably be notified before release. Thanks.

Tested on setup built from source #maint/3.2/security
created a file
/opt/eucalyptus/etc/eucalyptus/iptables-preload
with the following content:
iptables -A INPUT -s 10.111.1.62 -j DROP
After running service eucalyptus-cc cleanrestart
I could ping CC from 10.111.1.62
worked with alice to unit test . it passed .

verified that fix works when iptables rules are saved with iptables-save > 
/etc/eucalyptus/iptables-preload
